                                                    Politico
A daily report on the intersection of health care and technology 

            By 
David Pittman

09/15/15, 10:03 AM EDT
With help from Darius Tahir (@DariusTahir) and Arthur Allen (@ArthurAllen202 ) 
HEALTH IT COMPLAINT SITE COMING THIS WEEK: An HHS spokeswoman says an ONC website where EHR users can voice complaints — including allegations of information blocking, safety concerns and questions about performance of certified products — will launch later this week. ONC wanted to work out kinks and bugs on the site before making it publicly available. The problem is that acting Deputy National Coordinator Jon White’s blog announcing the site went live Friday and links to a page showing an error message. Interested readers have had a ball poking fun at that. A timing issue on HHS’s end had the two launching out of sync--so refrain from your HealthCare.gov jokes.
eHealth tweet of the day: @deansittig: This might be my favorite @ONC_HealthIT SNAFU of all-time ... You are not authorized to access this page. http://t.co/5Tg9PuvrYM
IS HEALTH IT SPURRING HOSPITAL MERGERS?: American Hospital Association CEO Rick Pollack told the House Judiciary Committee that he thought so, during a hearing last week on competition in health care. He estimated that hospitals will spend between $20 million and $200 million on EHRs each year depending on their size, and that dollar amount is unmanageable for smaller hospitals. The result: They merge, creating fewer players in a given market. “The fundamental restructuring that CMS anticipates in response to its alternative reimbursement models will undoubtedly come with a high cost that will be particularly difficult to bear for small and stand-alone hospitals,” Pollack testified. Pros get Darius’s full story here: http://politico.pro/1iKqx21 
Welcome to Tuesday morning eHealth where even your crusty scribe is touched by this story of an Oklahoma man reunited with the wedding ring that he lost in a New York lake nearly 40 years ago. It washed ashore and a neighbor found it. http://apne.ws/1EYWLAI Send us news at dpittman@politico.com and connect with us on Twitter @David_Pittman, @arthurallen202, @DariusTahir @ POLITICOPro, @Morning_eHealth.
DAYS TILL THE MOVE TO ICD-10: 15
BATTLE OVER STAGE 3 TIMING CONTINUES: Dedicated reader and DirectTrust President and CEO David Kibbe tells us — in response to Monday’s news about doctors increasing their fight for a delay in Stage 3 rulemaking — that he sees a fight brewing between doctors and EHR vendors. Physicians, he says, don’t want problematic technology to be sealed in amber--or rather, they don't want to be sealed in the amber of problematic technology--through the finalization of the Stage 3 regs. “There is tremendous pent up anger about being ‘locked in’ by the vendors,” Kibbe says. “And the providers see that they need more room to move, not less, in the near future. Stage 3 is viewed as a way for the some vendors to lock in at a higher level of complexity.” Kibbe says the smart money is on EHR vendors who can provider higher customer service at lower prices. 
REACTION TO RECENT GAG CLAUSE STORY: @EmilyFPeters: Compare to @PracticeFusion that has been gag-order free (and also free in price) since the start: http://bit.ly/1J8Vke3 
BIG DATA: ALL TALK, LITTLE ACTION: Half of large hospitals surveyed reported not having a clear strategy for using data analytics, a recent survey from the Deloitte Center for Health Solutions found. Only five of the 50 hospitals who responded to the survey said they expected their analytics spending to grow significantly in the next three years. “Many health systems have yet to take advantage of the capabilities that analytics can bring to meet their enterprise objectives,” the report found. The authors do expect analytics to play a greater role as health insurers move to value-based purchasing. The report: http://bit.ly/1ORmbQO 
TIME FOR CONSUMER DATA IN HEALTH CARE?: This post from the Commonwealth Fund asks that question. If clinicians know who is more likely to take their medication beforehand, for example, it could change the treatment plan. “Segmenting patients by their motivations and behaviors can make it easier to target interventions and deploy resources to those most in need of them," says Cynthia Kilroy, a senior vice president at Optum, the health services consulting firm. Combining that information with clinical data "is the next frontier in population health," she says. The post: http://bit.ly/1NsiRhF 
NURSES THINK MORE DATA SHOULD BE IN EHRs: The American Academy of Nursing think it’s important to capture social and behavioral determinants of health in EHRs, and on Monday released a policy paper outlining what EHR vendors, hospitals, clinicians and funders need to do to make that a reality. The paper follows an April 2014 Institute of Medicine report that similar recommendations. The AAN paper: http://bit.ly/1KiIOth 
QUALCOMM LIFE EXTENDS ITS REACH: Qualcomm, through its Life subsidiary, is extending its reach further into the medical device world. The company’s 2net product has long integrated data from home-based health gadgets with doctors’ EHRs. Qualcomm’s acquisition, announced Monday, of Capsule Technologie will serve largely the same purpose for medical devices located in the hospital. It’s hard to tell exactly how many hospitals are converting medical device results into digital data for the EHR’s consumption; industry analysts pin that number at roughly 18 percent.  HEALTH IT SAFETY, A CONSIDERATION: A pair of health IT heavy hitters — Hardeep Singh and Dean Sittig — have taken to the pages of the British Medical Journal’s Quality and Safety publication to discuss improving the patient safety characteristics of software. Singh and Sittig believe patient safety problems stem not only from health IT technology, but its implementation and the way clinicians interact with it and each other. The problems, then, are systemic. For the authors, health IT needs to be safe, and safely used, but also used to improve safety. To accomplish those tasks, the authors suggest better measurement and collaboration — neither of which is occurring to their satisfaction yet. Their paper: http://bit.ly/1OrkfQZ 
WHAT WE'RE CLICKING:
Drug companies hand out Fitbits to better track patients around the clock: http://bloom.bg/1KlBBgp
‘Bedless hospital” in suburban Detroit operates entirely on telemedicine: http://bit.ly/1gn0dsQ 
Google has been pretty quiet on its interest in health care: http://on.recode.net/1LsJVHG 
Survey gives details on what users think about specific EHRs: http://bit.ly/1LdbMjr 
DEBRIEF INTERVIEW WITH STAN COLLENDER: What’s at stake in the budget showdown on Capitol Hill? The renowned budget expert tells us how the protracted negotiations hurt government agencies, weighs the consequences of a government shutdown and fills us in on which key players he’s watching right now. Find out on this week’s Debrief video from The Agenda: http://politi.co/1KnnC9N
Tips, comments, suggestions? Send them along via email to our team: Arthur Allen (aallen@politico.com, @ArthurAllen202), David Pittman (dpittman@politico.com, @David_Pittman), Darius Tahir (dtahir@politico.com, @DariusTahir) and Aubree Eliza Weaver (aweaver@politico.com, @AubreeEWeaver)

                                            By 
                                                    Ian Bremmer


                                            By 
Blake Hounshell


                                            By 
                                                    Jason Zengerle


                                            By 
                                                    Daniel Yergin

David Pittman is an eHealth reporter for POLITICO Pro.
Before joining POLITICO in May 2014, Pittman served as the lone Washington reporter for the health news website MedPage Today, covering nearly all aspects of health policy from Medicare and Medicaid to the Affordable Care Act and Capitol Hill. He has also covered science and regulatory policy for trade newsletter company FDAnews and the weekly newsmagazine Chemical & Engineering News. Pittman got his start in journalism covering healthcare for the daily newspaper in the West Texas town of Amarillo.
Pittman holds bachelor's degrees in journalism and chemistry from the University of Georgia, where he graduated in 2006. While in Athens, Pittman worked as a staff writer of The Red & Black and eventually became editor-in-chief, pestering school administrators. Like any good Southerner, he prefers his tea sweet, chicken fried and fall Saturdays reserved for college football. He is also surviving as an Atlanta Braves fan in a town full of Washington Nationals supporters.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
